Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN EAGER: Harnessing Light Sheet and Light Field Microscopy to Visualize Dynamic Adaptations to Neural Activity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This BRAIN EAGER will support an interdisciplinary team of investigators to jointly develop and deploy optimized light sheet microscopy and novel genetically encoded probes to image synaptic function in the intact nervous system. This team will optimize a novel 3D imaging microscope, in which multi-photon light sheet illumination is combined with light field microscopy to permit a single snapshot to capture the full 3D image, enabling the team to visualize these probes with unprecedented speed and coverage. They will also develop new genetically encoded glutamate and calcium probes, targeted to defined synaptic compartments, to optimize signal magnitude and report synaptic activity with high sensitivity and fidelity. These innovations will be exploited to synergistically visualize synaptic structure and monitor glutamate and calcium dynamics in the intact Drosophila central nervous system.

Although these tools could be used in a variety of settings in the vertebrate or the invertebrate nervous system, these will be first applied to address the fundamental relationship between sleep and synaptic plasticity. Although sleep is ancient, the essential biological function of this behavior remains a great mystery of science. This project will explore the exciting possibility that a fundamental function of sleep, operating at the level of individual neurons and synapses, is the homeostatic modulation of synaptic strength. Addressing this hypothesis has been beyond our capabilities because visualizing neural activity in the central nervous system during sleep-wake behavior has been limited in both speed and resolution. Through a combination of new genetically encoded probes reporting synaptic structure and activity and cutting-edge imaging approaches, this project will permit the imaging of synapses over time without perturbing the nervous system or the sleep-wake cycle. These test experiments will advance our knowledge of the complex, fundamental, and poorly understood signaling systems that orchestrate the homeostatic control of synaptic strength, and their modulation during sleep behavior. The education and outreach activities of the research team will be intimately linked with their research programs, and will include a research project with local inner-city Los Angeles high school students investigating sleep and circadian behavior. In addition, a new undergraduate course will be developed exploring the biological functions of sleep.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF EAGER project, three complementary approaches were used to define dynamic adaptations in the brain during sleep and wake behavioral states. First, visualization and localization of types of neuronal and glial cell types in the adult Drosophila nervous system were defined. Next, the overlap of these cells with expression of a gene encoding a novel regulator of sleep homeostasis, named insomniac, was used to delineate a possible set of neurons involved in sleep need (Figure 1). Second, we explored and developed novel imaging strategies, based on light sheet and light field microscopy, to enable whole-brain imaging of the adult Drosophila nervous system at single-cell resolution. Specifically, we developed an imaging and analysis pipeline using light sheet microscopy, known as Selective Plan Illumination Microscopy (SPIM). This development allows the detection of ex vivo whole-brain activity patterns and the visualization of changes in neural and synaptic activity patterns during normal sleep/wake behavior and also in conditions following sleep deprivation (Figure 3). Further, we successfully combined the contrast-enhancing illumination strategy of SPIM with the fast volumetric imaging capability of light field microscopy to create a new imaging modality that we term Selective Volume Illumination Microscopy, which now enables fast whole-brain imaging of synaptic events in the live adult Drosophila brain at single-neuron resolution (Figure 4). Finally, a powerful method to profile translational rates of gene expression was used to determine changes in gene expression in specific neuronal classes following sleep deprivation compared with rested states.

 

This ambitious project resulted in the revelation of new neural circuitry related to the control of sleep need, sleep behavior, and potentially sleep homeostasis. These are likely to be evolutionarily conserved and may inspire investigations of related circuits in other species. In addition, this work provided key insights into the nature of gene expression programs that are specifically modulated in the nervous system during sleep/wake behavior and following sleep deprivation. Importantly, new reagents for monitoring gene expression and neural activity in specific cells have been developed and distributed to other researchers. The imaging technologies that were developed and refined as a result of this project, SPIM and SVIM, should be applicable for neuroimaging of other model organisms including C. elegans, zebrafish, and mice. The high resolution capability of SPIM and the high speed capability of SVIM point to a future combining these modalities together into an integrated imaging platform that will enable both structural and functional interrogation of brain-wide neural circuits across a wide range of spatial and temporal scales in intact behaving animals.
